Introduction to Real Analysis, Volume I (Jiri Lebl, 2025) -- Chapter 01 -- Section 01

Definition 1.1.1: An ordered set is a set Unknown identifier `S`S with a relation such that (i) (trichotomy) for all Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx y Unknown identifier `S`S, exactly one of Unknown identifier `x`sorry < sorry : Propx < Unknown identifier `y`y, Unknown identifier `x`sorry = sorry : Propx = Unknown identifier `y`y, or Unknown identifier `y`sorry < sorry : Propy < Unknown identifier `x`x holds, and (ii) (transitivity) if Unknown identifier `x`sorry < sorry : Propx < Unknown identifier `y`y and Unknown identifier `y`sorry < sorry : Propy < Unknown identifier `z`z then Unknown identifier `x`sorry < sorry : Propx < Unknown identifier `z`z. We write Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx Unknown identifier `y`y if Unknown identifier `x`sorry < sorry : Propx < Unknown identifier `y`y or Unknown identifier `x`sorry = sorry : Propx = Unknown identifier `y`y, and define , analogously.

structure OrderedSet ( : Type u) where lt : Prop trichotomous : x y, lt x y x = y lt y x irrefl : x, lt x x trans : {x y z}, lt x y lt y z lt x z
namespace OrderedSetvariable { : Type u} (S : OrderedSet )

The weak order associated to an ordered set.

def le (x y : ) : Prop := S.lt x y x = y

The axioms of an ordered set give a strict total order in mathlib's sense.

theorem toStrictTotalOrder : IsStrictTotalOrder S.lt := by refine { trichotomous := S.trichotomous, irrefl := S.irrefl, trans := ?_ } intro a b c h1 h2 exact S.trans h1 h2

A strict total order in mathlib yields the ordered-set structure described in Definition 1.1.1.

def ofStrictTotalOrder {lt : Prop} (h : IsStrictTotalOrder lt) : OrderedSet := by refine { lt := lt, trichotomous := ?_, irrefl := ?_, trans := ?_ } exact h.trichotomous exact h.irrefl intro x y z hxy hyz exact h.trans x y z hxy hyz
end OrderedSet

Definition 1.1.2: For a subset Unknown identifier `E`E of an ordered set Unknown identifier `S`S, (i) Unknown identifier `E`E is bounded above if there is Unknown identifier `b`b with Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx Unknown identifier `b`b for all Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx Unknown identifier `E`E, and such a Unknown identifier `b`b is an upper bound; (ii) Unknown identifier `E`E is bounded below if there is Unknown identifier `b`b with Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx Unknown identifier `b`b for all Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx Unknown identifier `E`E, and such a Unknown identifier `b`b is a lower bound; (iii) an upper bound Unknown identifier `b`b is a least upper bound (supremum) if Unknown identifier `b`sorry sorry : Propb Unknown identifier `b`b for all upper bounds Unknown identifier `b`b, written Unknown identifier `sup`sorry = sorry : Propsup E = Unknown identifier `b`b; (iv) a lower bound Unknown identifier `b`b is a greatest lower bound (infimum) if Unknown identifier `b`sorry sorry : Propb Unknown identifier `b`b for all lower bounds Unknown identifier `b`b, written Unknown identifier `inf`sorry = sorry : Propinf E = Unknown identifier `b`b. A set bounded above and below is called bounded.

namespace OrderedSetvariable { : Type u} (S : OrderedSet ) (E : Set )

An element bounding every member of Unknown identifier `E`E above.

def IsUpperBound (b : ) : Prop := x, x E S.le x b

An element bounding every member of Unknown identifier `E`E below.

def IsLowerBound (b : ) : Prop := x, x E S.le b x

Existence of an upper bound for Unknown identifier `E`E.

def BoundedAbove : Prop := b, IsUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) b

Existence of a lower bound for Unknown identifier `E`E.

def BoundedBelow : Prop := b, IsLowerBound (S := S) (E := E) b

An upper bound that is minimal among all upper bounds.

def IsLeastUpperBound (b : ) : Prop := IsUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) b b, IsUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) b S.le b b

A lower bound that is maximal among all lower bounds.

def IsGreatestLowerBound (b : ) : Prop := IsLowerBound (S := S) (E := E) b b, IsLowerBound (S := S) (E := E) b S.le b b

A set that is both bounded above and bounded below.

def Bounded : Prop := BoundedAbove (S := S) (E := E) BoundedBelow (S := S) (E := E)
noncomputable def supremum (h : b, IsLeastUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) b) : := Classical.choose hnoncomputable def infimum (h : b, IsGreatestLowerBound (S := S) (E := E) b) : := Classical.choose hlemma supremum_spec (h : b, IsLeastUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) b) : IsLeastUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) (supremum (S := S) (E := E) h) := by classical simpa [supremum] using Classical.choose_spec hlemma infimum_spec (h : b, IsGreatestLowerBound (S := S) (E := E) b) : IsGreatestLowerBound (S := S) (E := E) (infimum (S := S) (E := E) h) := by classical simpa [infimum] using Classical.choose_spec h

Definition 1.1.3: An ordered set has the least-upper-bound property if every nonempty subset that is bounded above has a least upper bound (supremum) in the set.

def LeastUpperBoundProperty : Prop := {E : Set }, E.Nonempty BoundedAbove (S := S) (E := E) b, IsLeastUpperBound (S := S) (E := E) b

Example 1.1.4: The subset {x | x ^ 2 < 2} : Set {x : | x^2 < 2} has no supremum in : Type, so : Type does not have the least-upper-bound property. Equivalently, there is no rational square root of 2 : 2.

theorem rat_sq_lt_two_has_no_sup : q : , IsLUB {x : | x * x < (2 : )} q := by classical intro h rcases h with q, hq let S : Set := {x : | x * x < (2 : )} have h_upper : x : , x S x q := by intro x hx [pow_two] using hx'' have hx_sq : (x : ) ^ 2 < (Real.sqrt 2) ^ 2 := by simpa [Real.sq_sqrt (by norm_num : 0 (2 : ))] using hx' have h_abs : |(x : )| < Real.sqrt 2 := by have h_abs' := (sq_lt_sq.mp hx_sq) have h_abs_sqrt : |Real.sqrt 2| = Real.sqrt 2 := abs_of_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg _) simpa [h_abs_sqrt] using h_abs' exact (abs_lt.mp h_abs).2 by_cases hlt : (q : ) < Real.sqrt 2 obtain r, hqr, No rational number has square equal to 2 : 2.

theorem rational_sq_eq_two_absurd : x : , x * x = (2 : ) := by intro h rcases h with q, hq have hsq_real : (q : ) * (q : ) = (2 : ) := by exact_mod_cast hq have hsq_abs : Real.sqrt 2 = |(q : )| := by have hsq_pow : (q : ) ^ 2 = (2 : ) := by simpa [pow_two] using hsq_real have hsq_rt : Real.sqrt 2 = Real.sqrt ((q : ) ^ 2) := by simp [hsq_pow] simpa [Real.sqrt_sq_eq_abs] using hsq_rt exact (irrational_sqrt_two.ne_rat (|q|)) (by simpa [Rat.cast_abs] using hsq_abs)
section FieldAxiomsSectionvariable (F : Type u) [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F]

Definition 1.1.5: A field is a set Unknown identifier `F`F with addition and multiplication such that (A1) if then Unknown identifier `x`sorry + sorry sorry : Propx + Unknown identifier `y`y Unknown identifier `F`F; (A2) addition is commutative; (A3) addition is associative; (A4) there is 0 sorry : Prop0 Unknown identifier `F`F with 0 + sorry = sorry : Prop0 + Unknown identifier `x`x = Unknown identifier `x`x; (A5) every Unknown identifier `x`x has an additive inverse -sorry : -Unknown identifier `x`x with Unknown identifier `x`sorry + -sorry = 0 : Propx + (-Unknown identifier `x`x) = 0; (M1) if then Unknown identifier `x`sorry * sorry sorry : Propx * Unknown identifier `y`y Unknown identifier `F`F; (M2) multiplication is commutative; (M3) multiplication is associative; (M4) there is 1 sorry : Prop1 Unknown identifier `F`F with 1 * sorry = sorry : Prop1 * Unknown identifier `x`x = Unknown identifier `x`x and 1 0 : Prop1 0; (M5) every Unknown identifier `x`sorry 0 : Propx 0 has a multiplicative inverse Unknown identifier `x`sorry : ?m.1x with Unknown identifier `x`sorry * sorry = 1 : Propx * failed to synthesize Inv Hint: Additional diagnostic information may be available using the `set_option diagnostics true` command.Unknown identifier `x`x = 1; and (D) distributivity Unknown identifier `x`sorry * (sorry + sorry) = sorry * sorry + sorry * sorry : Propx * (Unknown identifier `y`y + Unknown identifier `z`z) = Unknown identifier `x`x * Unknown identifier `y`y + Unknown identifier `x`x * Unknown identifier `z`z holds.

structure FieldAxioms (F : Type u) [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] : Prop where add_comm : x y : F, x + y = y + x add_assoc : x y z : F, (x + y) + z = x + (y + z) zero_add : x : F, 0 + x = x add_left_neg : x : F, x + (-x) = 0 mul_comm : x y : F, x * y = y * x mul_assoc : x y z : F, (x * y) * z = x * (y * z) one_mul : x : F, (1 : F) * x = x mul_inv_cancel : {x : F}, x 0 x * x = (1 : F) distrib : x y z : F, x * (y + z) = x * y + x * z one_ne_zero : (1 : F) (0 : F)
variable (F : Type u)

Mathlib's Field.{u} (K : Type u) : Type uField structure satisfies the axioms in Definition 1.1.5.

lemma field_axioms_of_field [Field F] : FieldAxioms (F := F) := by refine ?add_comm, ?add_assoc, ?zero_add, ?add_left_neg, ?mul_comm, ?mul_assoc, ?one_mul, ?mul_inv_cancel, ?distrib, ?one_ne_zero intro x y; exact add_comm x y intro x y z; exact add_assoc x y z intro x; exact zero_add x intro x; simp intro x y; exact mul_comm x y intro x y z; exact mul_assoc x y z intro x; exact one_mul x intro x hx; simpa using (mul_inv_cancel (a := x) hx) intro x y z; simpa using (mul_add x y z) exact one_ne_zero

From the field axioms we can derive the right identity for addition.

lemma FieldAxioms.add_zero [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) (x : F) : x + 0 = x := by have := h.zero_add x simpa [h.add_comm x 0] using this

From the field axioms we can derive right multiplication by 1 : 1.

lemma FieldAxioms.mul_one [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) (x : F) : x * (1 : F) = x := by have := h.one_mul x simpa [h.mul_comm x 1] using this

From the field axioms we obtain right distributivity.

lemma FieldAxioms.right_distrib [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) (x y z : F) : (x + y) * z = x * z + y * z := by calc (x + y) * z = z * (x + y) := by simp [h.mul_comm] _ = z * x + z * y := h.distrib _ _ _ _ = x * z + y * z := by simp [h.mul_comm]

From the field axioms we can show that Unknown identifier `x`sorry * 0 = 0 : Propx * 0 = 0.

lemma FieldAxioms.mul_zero [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) (x : F) : x * (0 : F) = 0 := by have hzero : x * 0 + -(x * 0) = x * 0 + x * 0 + -(x * 0) := by have hx0 : x * 0 = x * 0 + x * 0 := by have := h.distrib x 0 0 simpa [h.zero_add] using this simpa using congrArg (fun t => t + -(x * 0)) hx0 have hleft : x * 0 + -(x * 0) = 0 := by simpa using h.add_left_neg (x * 0) have hright : x * 0 + x * 0 + -(x * 0) = x * 0 := by calc x * 0 + x * 0 + -(x * 0) = x * 0 + (x * 0 + -(x * 0)) := by simpa using h.add_assoc (x * 0) (x * 0) (-(x * 0)) _ = x * 0 + 0 := by simp [h.add_left_neg] _ = x * 0 := by simp [h.add_zero] have : 0 = x * 0 := by calc 0 = x * 0 + x * 0 + -(x * 0) := by calc 0 = x * 0 + -(x * 0) := by simpa [eq_comm] using hleft _ = x * 0 + x * 0 + -(x * 0) := hzero _ = x * 0 := hright simpa [eq_comm] using this

From the field axioms we can show that 0 * sorry = 0 : Prop0 * Unknown identifier `x`x = 0.

lemma FieldAxioms.zero_mul [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) (x : F) : (0 : F) * x = 0 := by calc (0 : F) * x = x * 0 := h.mul_comm _ _ _ = 0 := FieldAxioms.mul_zero (F := F) (h := h) x

Construct a mathlib Field.{u} (K : Type u) : Type uField structure from the axioms in Definition 1.1.5.

noncomputable def field_structure_from_axioms [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) : Field F := by classical -- First, build the commutative-ring structure from the axioms. let h_neg_add_cancel : a : F, -a + a = (0 : F) := by intro a calc (-a) + a = a + (-a) := by simpa using (h.add_comm (-a) a) _ = 0 := h.add_left_neg a letI commRing : CommRing F := CommRing.ofMinimalAxioms (R := F) (add_assoc := h.add_assoc) (zero_add := h.zero_add) (neg_add_cancel := h_neg_add_cancel) (mul_assoc := h.mul_assoc) (mul_comm := h.mul_comm) (one_mul := h.one_mul) (left_distrib := h.distrib) -- Nontriviality follows from `1 0`. haveI : Nontrivial F := 1, 0, h.one_ne_zero -- Every element is either a unit or zero, thanks to the given inverse axiom. have h_units : a : F, IsUnit a a = 0 := by intro a by_cases ha : a = 0 right; exact ha left refine a, a, ?h, ?h, rfl exact h.mul_inv_cancel ha calc a * a = a * a := h.mul_comm _ _ _ = 1 := h.mul_inv_cancel ha -- Turn this into a field structure. exact Field.ofIsUnitOrEqZero (R := F) h_units

The axioms in Definition 1.1.5 recover the existence of a mathlib Field.{u} (K : Type u) : Type uField structure.

lemma field_of_field_axioms [Add F] [Mul F] [Zero F] [One F] [Neg F] [Inv F] (h : FieldAxioms (F := F)) : Nonempty (Field F) := by exact field_structure_from_axioms (F := F) h

The book's axioms for a field are equivalent to the existence of a mathlib Field.{u} (K : Type u) : Type uField structure using the same operations.

theorem field_iff_field_axioms : ( inst : Field F, (by let _ : Field F := inst; exact FieldAxioms (F := F))) Nonempty (Field F) := by classical constructor rintro inst, _ exact inst intro h rcases h with hField refine hField, ?_ let _ : Field F := hField exact field_axioms_of_field (F := F)

Example 1.1.6: The rationals : Type form a field, while the integers : Type fail axiom (M5) because 2 : 2 has no multiplicative inverse; this is the only field axiom that does not hold for : Type.

theorem rationals_field : Nonempty (Field ) := by exact inferInstance

The multiplicative inverse required by (M5) for does not exist.

theorem two_mul_eq_one_int_absurd : x : , (2 : ) * x = 1 := by intro h rcases h with x, hx have hdiv : (2 : ) (1 : ) := x, hx.symm have : False := by norm_num at hdiv exact this

The usual ring structure on the integers does not extend to a field structure.

theorem integers_not_field : IsField := by exact Int.not_isField
end FieldAxiomsSection

Definition 1.1.7: An ordered field is a field equipped with a strict total order such that (i) Unknown identifier `x`sorry < sorry : Propx < Unknown identifier `y`y implies Unknown identifier `x`sorry + sorry < sorry + sorry : Propx + Unknown identifier `z`z < Unknown identifier `y`y + Unknown identifier `z`z for all Unknown identifier `x`x y z, and (ii) 0 < sorry : Prop0 < Unknown identifier `x`x and 0 < sorry : Prop0 < Unknown identifier `y`y imply 0 < sorry * sorry : Prop0 < Unknown identifier `x`x * Unknown identifier `y`y. Elements with 0 < sorry : Prop0 < Unknown identifier `x`x are positive, those with Unknown identifier `x`sorry < 0 : Propx < 0 are negative, 0 < sorry sorry = 0 : Prop0 < Unknown identifier `x`x Unknown identifier `x`x = 0 are nonnegative, and Unknown identifier `x`sorry < 0 sorry = 0 : Propx < 0 Unknown identifier `x`x = 0 are nonpositive.

structure OrderedFieldAxioms (F : Type u) [Field F] [LT F] : Prop where order : IsStrictTotalOrder F ( < ) add_lt_add : {x y z : F}, x < y x + z < y + z mul_pos : {x y : F}, 0 < x 0 < y 0 < x * y
section OrderedFieldTerminologyvariable (F : Type u) [Field F] [LT F]

An element is positive if it is greater than zero.

def isPositive (x : F) : Prop := 0 < x

An element is negative if it is less than zero.

def isNegative (x : F) : Prop := x < 0

An element is nonnegative if it is positive or zero.

def isNonnegative (x : F) : Prop := 0 < x x = 0

An element is nonpositive if it is negative or zero.

def isNonpositive (x : F) : Prop := x < 0 x = 0
end OrderedFieldTerminologyvariable (F : Type u)

Mathlib's ordered ring structure (Field.{u} (K : Type u) : Type uField together with a linear order and compatibility axioms) satisfies the ordered-field axioms in Definition 1.1.7.

lemma orderedFieldAxioms_of_isStrictOrderedRing [Field F] [LinearOrder F] [IsStrictOrderedRing F] : OrderedFieldAxioms (F := F) := by refine ?order, ?add_lt_add, ?mul_pos infer_instance intro x y z hxy simpa [add_comm] using add_lt_add_right hxy z intro x y hx hy exact mul_pos hx hy

The book's ordered-field axioms are equivalent to the existence of a mathlib structure using the same operations.

theorem orderedField_iff_isStrictOrderedRing [Field F] [LinearOrder F] : OrderedFieldAxioms (F := F) IsStrictOrderedRing F := by constructor intro h have add_le_add_left : a b : F, a b c, a + c b + c := by intro a b hab c rcases lt_or_eq_of_le hab with hlt | hEq exact (h.add_lt_add (z := c) hlt).le simp [hEq] letI : IsOrderedAddMonoid F := { add_le_add_left := add_le_add_left add_le_add_right := by intro a b hab c simpa [add_comm] using (add_le_add_left a b hab c) } have hzero_lt_one : (0 : F) < 1 := by rcases lt_trichotomy (0 : F) (1 : F) with hlt | hEq | hgt exact hlt exact (False.elim (one_ne_zero hEq.symm)) have hneg : (0 : F) < (-1 : F) := by have h' := h.add_lt_add (x := 1) (y := 0) (z := -1) hgt simpa using h' have hpos : (0 : F) < (-1 : F) * (-1 : F) := h.mul_pos hneg hneg simpa using hpos letI : ZeroLEOneClass F := hzero_lt_one.le refine IsStrictOrderedRing.of_mul_pos (R := F) (mul_pos := ?_) intro a b ha hb exact h.mul_pos ha hb intro h exact orderedFieldAxioms_of_isStrictOrderedRing (F := F)
section OrderedFieldInequalitiesvariable {F : Type u} [Field F] [LinearOrder F] [IsStrictOrderedRing F]variable {x y z w : F}

Proposition 1.1.8: Let Unknown identifier `F`F be an ordered field and Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Propx y z w Unknown identifier `F`F. (i) If Unknown identifier `x`sorry > 0 : Propx > 0, then -sorry < 0 : Prop-Unknown identifier `x`x < 0 (and conversely). (ii) If Unknown identifier `x`sorry > 0 : Propx > 0 and Unknown identifier `y`sorry < sorry : Propy < Unknown identifier `z`z, then Unknown identifier `x`sorry * sorry < sorry * sorry : Propx * Unknown identifier `y`y < Unknown identifier `x`x * Unknown identifier `z`z. (iii) If Unknown identifier `x`sorry < 0 : Propx < 0 and Unknown identifier `y`sorry < sorry : Propy < Unknown identifier `z`z, then Unknown identifier `x`sorry * sorry > sorry * sorry : Propx * Unknown identifier `y`y > Unknown identifier `x`x * Unknown identifier `z`z. (iv) If Unknown identifier `x`sorry 0 : Propx 0, then Unknown identifier `x`sorry ^ 2 > 0 : Propx^2 > 0. (v) If , then . (vi) If , then Unknown identifier `x`sorry ^ 2 < sorry ^ 2 : Propx^2 < Unknown identifier `y`y^2. theorem orderedField_neg_of_pos_iff : x > 0 -x < 0 := by -- `0 < x` is equivalent to `-x < 0` via the positivity of a double negation simp
theorem orderedField_mul_lt_mul_left_of_pos (hx : 0 < x) (hyz : y < z) : x * y < x * z := by exact mul_lt_mul_of_pos_left hyz hxtheorem orderedField_mul_gt_mul_left_of_neg (hx : x < 0) (hyz : y < z) : x * y > x * z := by exact mul_lt_mul_of_neg_left hyz hxtheorem orderedField_sq_pos_of_ne_zero (hx : x 0) : x ^ 2 > 0 := by simpa using (sq_pos_of_ne_zero hx)theorem orderedField_inv_bounds_of_lt (hx : 0 < x) (hxy : x < y) : 0 < (1 / y) 1 / y < 1 / x := by have hy : 0 < y := lt_trans hx hxy have hinv_y : 0 < (1 / y) := by simpa [one_div] using inv_pos.mpr hy have hinv_lt : 1 / y < 1 / x := by simpa [one_div] using (one_div_lt_one_div_of_lt hx hxy) exact hinv_y, hinv_lttheorem orderedField_sq_lt_sq_of_pos_of_lt (hx : 0 < x) (hxy : x < y) : x ^ 2 < y ^ 2 := by have hy : 0 < y := lt_trans hx hxy have h : x * x < x * y := mul_lt_mul_of_pos_left hxy hx have h : x * y < y * y := mul_lt_mul_of_pos_right hxy hy have hxy' : x * x < y * y := lt_trans h h simpa [pow_two] using hxy'theorem orderedField_add_le_add (hxy : x y) (hzw : z w) : x + z y + w := by exact add_le_add hxy hzwend OrderedFieldInequalities

Proposition 1.1.9: In an ordered field, if Unknown identifier `x`sorry * sorry > 0 : Propx * Unknown identifier `y`y > 0 then either both Unknown identifier `x`x and Unknown identifier `y`y are positive or both are negative.

theorem pos_mul_same_sign {F : Type u} [Field F] [LinearOrder F] [IsStrictOrderedRing F] {x y : F} (h : x * y > 0) : (0 < x 0 < y) (x < 0 y < 0) := by -- Directly unpack the characterization of a positive product. simpa using (mul_pos_iff.mp h)

Example 1.1.10: The complex numbers = {x | sorry} : Prop = {typeclass instance problem is stuck HAdd ?m.12 ?m.13 ?m.1 Note: Lean will not try to resolve this typeclass instance problem because the first and second type arguments to `HAdd` are metavariables. These arguments must be fully determined before Lean will try to resolve the typeclass. Hint: Adding type annotations and supplying implicit arguments to functions can give Lean more information for typeclass resolution. For example, if you have a variable `x` that you intend to be a `Nat`, but Lean reports it as having an unresolved type like `?m`, replacing `x` with `(x : Nat)` can get typeclass resolution un-stuck.x + iy | x y } satisfy Unknown identifier `I`sorry ^ 2 = -1 : PropI^2 = -1 and form a field. No ordering of : Type can make it an ordered field: in every ordered field, -1 < 0 : Prop-1 < 0 and squares of nonzero elements are positive, but sorry ^ 2 = -1 : Prop(Unknown identifier `I`I : )^2 = -1.

theorem complex_field : Nonempty (Field ) := by exact inferInstance
lemma complex_I_square_pos [LinearOrder ] [IsStrictOrderedRing ] : (0 : ) < (Complex.I : ) ^ 2 := by simpa using (orderedField_sq_pos_of_ne_zero (x := (Complex.I : )) Complex.I_ne_zero)

There is no way to equip : Type with a linear order making it an ordered field.

theorem complex_not_linearOrderedField : _ : LinearOrder , IsStrictOrderedRing := by intro h rcases h with hlin, hstrict -- Use the order from the hypothesis in the rest of the argument. let _ : LinearOrder := hlin let _ : IsStrictOrderedRing := hstrict -- In any ordered field, the square of a nonzero element is positive. have hpos : (0 : ) < (-1) := by have hIpos : (0 : ) < (Complex.I : ) ^ 2 := complex_I_square_pos simpa [Complex.I_sq] using hIpos -- But `-1` is negative because `1` is positive. have hneg : (-1 : ) < 0 := (orderedField_neg_of_pos_iff (x := (1 : ))).1 (show (0 : ) < 1 from zero_lt_one) exact (lt_asymm hneg hpos).elim

Proposition 1.1.11: In an ordered field with the least-upper-bound property, every nonempty subset that is bounded below has an infimum.

theorem infimum_exists_of_bddBelow {F : Type u} [Field F] [LinearOrder F] [IsStrictOrderedRing F] (lub : {E : Set F}, E.Nonempty BddAbove E b, IsLUB E b) {A : Set F} (hA : A.Nonempty) (hB : BddBelow A) : infA, IsGLB A infA := by classical rcases hA with a, ha let B : Set F := (fun x : F => -x) '' A have hB_nonempty : B.Nonempty := -a, a, ha, rfl rcases hB with b, hb have hB_bddAbove : BddAbove B := by refine -b, ?_ intro y hy rcases hy with x, hxA, rfl have hb_le : b x := hb hxA have hneg : -x -b := neg_le_neg hb_le simpa using hneg obtain c, hc := lub (E := B) hB_nonempty hB_bddAbove refine -c, ?_ constructor intro x hxA have hxB : -x B := x, hxA, rfl have hxc : -x c := hc.1 hxB have hneg : -c x := by have := neg_le_neg hxc simpa [neg_neg] using this exact hneg intro b hbLower have hb_upper : -b upperBounds B := by intro y hy rcases hy with x, hxA, rfl have hbx : b x := hbLower hxA have hneg : -x -b := neg_le_neg hbx simpa using hneg have hcle : c -b := hc.2 hb_upper have hneg : b -c := by have := neg_le_neg hcle simpa [neg_neg] using this exact hneg
